so this week I went to quite a few
exhibitions which have recently opened
the first of which was Omaha sketchbook
like Gregory help and at Huxley parlour
it's a collection of images made over
the course of 15 years which explores
manhood in America specifically in Omaha
and images just a really great and it's
really interesting to experience the
work as an exhibition since the book is
displayed in a really different way
which perfectly segues to the book it's
constructed to look and feel like a book
cuz that helped and actually made whilst
shooting the photos well he took
construction paper which he found and
stuck in little contact prints himself
and made this kind of DIY book and Mac
has printed this amazing reproduction of
it where they've spot laminated every

print and it really does look like
they're stuck in I don't know how well

but it looks real it looks like proper
print stuck down not printed on the

the best book which was bought in a long

an exhibition of these insanely large
mandalas that she's made out of pieces
of butterfly wings which is pretty
strange there I'm not normally into
mandalas I don't really see the appeal
in them however there's something quite
mesmerizing about when they're this
insanely large that they can cover your
whole periphery you can get lost in it
and it was a cool experience and just
the scale of even the framing is
impressive it's a big feat of
engineering I guess
so yeah if you're into this I'd highly

British culture having an insight into

so recently i've also started two new
personal projects both of which are
collaborative with my friend Tom so I
thought I'd share with you some of the
early stages of images and just some
thoughts and directions so the first
project is kind of a response to some
writing which Tom's made is all about
growing up in suburbia I've just been
kind of ingesting poems and music that
he's made and then going out and just
see how I respond there's no real set
goal I think this is really nice because
it allows you to just be more loose and
just take more photos and then kind of
consolidate and edit it down later and
it's nice to just kind of get in the
swing of making something so I've been
taking the photos around dusk time
because I thought that'd be an
interesting different light which I
don't normally shoot in and then I
realized something which I thought was
maybe worth sharing when I took this
long exposure
of I guess a a night scape type thing
I've mentioned before that my Mamiya 7
has a pro mist filter on the lens which
is basically like a scratched up
diffused piece of glass which gives a
soft glow to the highlights and I hadn't
really utilized it that much until this
point where I realized this nighttime
photo with street lights in the kind of
light that was emitted from the street
lights was more pleasing than normal I
thought they had this really nice kind
of just glow so I decided to do some
side-by-side comparisons and take
another photo with them without the
filter just to see how much it does so I
think this works really well I think a
pretty interesting maybe if you're into
taking notes and photos the promess
filter is something you should check out
the second series of photos which I'm

which I think came out really well I

and then the second one utilized the

recreate a photo of the will of the wisp
which is glowing thing ghost who knows
it kind of spawns in swampy areas
initially I was planning on doing some
long exposures and kind of light
painting or using candles or something
to try and recreate a glow and what I
ended up doing was using my wireless
flash trigger to shoot directly into the
flash and then utilize the soft glow of
the promess filter that would kind of
diffuse it into this just kind of
ethereal blob of light and I have to say
it kind of worked perfectly
I think this sums up what I was trying
